content:
James tests the new Fiat 500
near some youths on bicycles,

and the Ascari A10,
just how fast is this thing?
Hello. Hello and welcome.
Thanks very much. Thank you.

Now, last year, you may remember
we borrowed some tractors

and we planted
25 acres of oilseed rape.

The idea was that we
were going to harvest it

and then turn the seeds
into juicy, eco-friendly petrol,

full of natural, dew-picked
farm-fresh goodness.

Unfortunately,
James bought the wrong seeds.

We ended up
with 500 gallons of...

And there's no other way
of saying this... Diesel.

Five hundred gallons
of haemorrhoid cream

would have been
more useful, honestly.

We hate diesel,
so we decided to burn it.

Even though
the three of us have

no racing experience,
we entered

the Britcar 24 Hour Race at
Silverstone with a diesel car.

Don't laugh, because although the idea of
us three racing is clearly preposterous,

the idea of a diesel isn't. Because this
year Audi won the 24 Hour of Le Mans race

in a diesel car, and largely because they
didn't have to waste time refuelling.

All we needed was a car,
so we got one.

And then while James was
moonlighting on his wine programme,

Jeremy and I went down to the
Top Gear technology centre.

Here it is, the crucible
of all our great inventions.
This is the car we bought.

It's a BMW 330d, four
years old, done 45,000 miles.
We paid 11 grand for it.

And now we must
turn it into a racing car

by bolting lots of
racing car bits to it.

The director of the Top Gear
technology centre, Steve,

would do all the trivial jobs like the
brakes, the engine, the suspension,

and the electronics,
while we did the big stuff.
I had to do the race seat.

Jeremy, meanwhile, had to
install the long-range fuel tank.
Got a hammer?

With that not done,
I checked on Hammond.
Yes, the office!

- That feels business-like.
- Hammond?

- What?
- Do you understand endurance racing?

- Yeah.
- 24-hour race, three drivers.
Do you want to hop out?

So let's just say
you do the first stint.

Here's the driver change. You
get out, the car's been refuelled,
it's my turn to get in.

- Come on.
- It will be a bit of a squeeze for you.

I grant you,
it will be a bit of a squeeze.

It won't be a bit of a
squeeze, mate. It will be...
Ah! There you go. You're in!

All the other cars...
Those are the noises of them.

Meanwhile,
back in the Top Gear pit...

"Jeremy,
you'd have to get a saw."
Well, yeah.

Right, I'll put the seat on
runners so it will be more boring.

Next, we needed
a drinks delivery system.

Most are rubbish, so I
made ours battery-powered.

Okay, so when you want
a drink, which you will,
you put that in your mouth.

Okay. Squeeze,
squeeze, squeeze.
I am squeezing it.

A-ha!
Does that work?

It's not brilliant,
if I'm honest.
Yeah, it's flawed.

To make it look like a racing
car, we needed sponsor's names.

But sadly, because
of BBC rules

we couldn't get real ones, so
we just sort of made some up.

Look at that, that looks
like a racing car already!

- It looks like a racing... It needed that, didn't it?
- It does.

With the car almost ready, our
thoughts turned to the race itself.

You know how I said, "How hard
can it be?" when we started this?
Yes.

If I'm honest, I think
it's going to be really hard.

I'm quite glad you said that 'cause it's
crossed my mind. I'm getting a bit nervous.

I don't want to win, but I want
people to take us seriously.

Yeah, I just think we're
going to look ridiculous.

We arrived at Silverstone,
assuming the Britcar 24

would be an amateur event
for beginners like us.
We were badly wrong.

In fact, our diesel Beemer would be
up against 200 mile an hour supercars.

The other drivers were
chisel-jawed and battle-hardened.

They had blue-chip sponsors,
tons of equipment.

They'd turned up
with laptops

and luxury motor homes
with girls in them.

Our motor home wasn't
quite as professional as that,
nor was our catering.
Nor was our car.
In fact, nothing was.

Then there was the
question of us three.

You do realise we are
the only people in this field,

the only people with
one of these on the back.

I meant... I did mean
to ask, what is it?
That means novice.

Everybody else has done
at least six races.

Worse still, Richard had
never been round Silverstone.

The sum total of our
experience is you've done...

I've done a charity race
in a Honda Civic.

- And you've done five laps in this?
- Five laps in this.

You've done no racing at all.
You've done some laps, but not in this.
I've done a race in a 2CV,

I have never driven this and
I've never been around Silver...
We're not in good shape.

A walk down the pits didn't
exactly cheer us up either.

- We haven't done that.
- No, we haven't got that.

- We haven't got this.
- We haven't got that.

No, we haven't got that. We haven't
got these. We haven't got these.

- Is this a diesel?
- Yeah... No...
What is it? An M3?

- So this is an M3 BMW with a...
- It's a lot better than ours.

- Is it a diesel? M3.
- No, no, it's a bit quicker than that.
An M3.

- Please be nice to us.
- No.
How can we get out of it?

I'm seriously thinking of
sitting down just before the race

and drinking
a bottle of vodka.

Soon, though,
it was time for qualifying.

What if I have to get out of
someone's way to let them go by?
I don't know.
I don't know.

This is, without any
question or shadow of doubt

- the scariest thing I've ever done.
- Yes.
I've broken me zip.
That's bad.

For qualifying, we had to do
a minimum of three laps each

and the quickest time
from our team would decide

our place on
the starting grid.
I went first.

Flat tram bridge. Don't lift,
don't lift, don't lift, don't lift!

I've got another M3
coming up behind me.

- He's ruining my bloody lap.
- What an absolute!

He ruined my lap.
The lap's gone.

Maybe Captain Slow
would have better luck.

Oh, my God,
911s everywhere!

Don't be intimidated,
just keep going.

May was back
astonishingly quickly.
In fact, too quickly.

- James, did you do three laps?
- Two.

- But you haven't done a fast lap.
- Yeah, I just did a fast lap.

- But you can't do it in two.
- I'm sure I did.

- You didn't.
- All right.
How could you not count?

Hammond, meanwhile, had
no idea where he was going.

This is Maggotts
or Becketts or Vale...
Or Chapel.

We'd planned to
leave Richard out there

so he could
learn the track,

but now we had to get him in
so James could go back out.

As cock-ups go, I've watched
Formula One since I was that high

and never seen
anybody, ever...

- Forget to do a flying lap.
- ...forget to do a flying lap.

Qualifying
was turning into a shambles.

And when we tuned into the
circuit TV, that went wrong as well.

- They're slower than us!
- There's a chest of drawers! And a table!

We were
a laughing stock,

but we still had
an ace up our sleeves,
a fourth driver.

Yeah, they weren't
ready for that!

Can he do
24 hours straight?

With The Stig at the
wheel, we were in business.

...two... 24...
We're not bottom!

- Boston Bowl!
- Let's go down there and mock.
Sadly, we couldn't.

Because this was
a 24-hour race,

we also had to do
three practice laps at night.

- My fear's come back badly.
- I know my fear's come back hideously.
Yeah, I'm really terrible.

Just looking at you
is making me more scared.

I went first, and it turned
out my fears were justified.

People are trying to get round
me, there's lights everywhere.

Jeez, I don't
remember anything!

This really is
all you can see.

You have to aim
for corners and just

sort of hope they're
still there. It's terrifying.

I've got nobody to follow.
Oh, God!
Then it was Jeremy's turn.

Holy cow,
I can't see a thing!

He tried to cure the lack
of visibility with speed.

I just took Bridge
corner flat. First time...
Oh! I'm off.

People behind must be
thinking, "Who is this clown?"

Amazingly, The Stig went faster
at night than he had in the day,

and put us an astonishing
42nd on the grid.

- Yeah!
- That's great.

Yeah.
Don't touch him.

With James'
qualifying in the bag,

everything looked
good for the race,
but then...

James, it's Richard.
What's happened? Tell us.

The throttle went mad, gearbox
seemed to explode, everything.
Hang on, I'm coming in.

We now had a good
starting spot on the grid,
but nothing to start with.

Our £11,000 wreck-mobile
was in serious trouble.
That's made a mess of them.

Our race chief reckoned we'd blown
the turbo, the clutch, and the flywheel.
But we never quit.

Top Gear technology centre,
isn't it?

While Steve
set about the car,

we set about
our high-energy supper.

I am not worried that
it's not going to be fixed.
Yeah, Steve will fix it.

The only worry I have is that if Steve
has to work through the night tonight

to fix it, when we do
the race tomorrow,

he has to work
through tomorrow night.
It's a three-day...
Yeah.

I'm not bothered about that
either, come to think of it.
So, to summarise,

the car was broken,
we were all rubbish,
James' zip was stuck

and we'd accidentally written
"arse biscuits" on the driver's door.

Kind of par for the course,
really, with Top Gear.

We just expected the race
to be the usual fare.

You know, everything would
catch fire, and then we'd all drown.

We were quite
looking forward to it.

And then we went to visit
the team that qualified last.
Yeah, to laugh at them.

Yeah, but they told us that they
qualified last the year before as well.

But by being consistent
and not making any mistakes,

their Golf diesel
finished 13th overall.

They'd beaten M3s, 911s,
and even the odd Viper.

Yeah, and this
gave us an idea.

We thought,
if we take this seriously,

maybe our BMW diesel
could finish in the top 10.

Mmm, well, we'll see
how that pans out later on.

But now it's time for the news
and there isn't any.

And even if there were,
we haven't got time for it

because we've got such
a packed programme.

So we must move on
to the 1950s. James?

Over the past few years,
many car manufacturers

have been reinventing their
old models from the past.

- Where you live.
- Thank you.

Volkswagen has given us
the new Beetle,

BMW, of course,
re-invented the Mini,

and now,
there's another one.

And here it is.
It's called the Fiat 500

and it's virtually
a carbon copy

of their legendary car from
the '50s which was called,
uh, the Fiat 500.

Now, the original car was
small and ruthlessly simple.

You could even buy spares
from your local newsagent's.

It was the last word in cheap,
utilitarian transport for the masses.

Now let me say
straight from the off

that this is not small, cheap,
utilitarian transport for the masses.

Under this retro body, it's
based on the current Fiat Panda.

Without wishing to get all "Bah!
Humbug" about it, the Panda is bigger,

it's more practical and
it's about a grand cheaper,

so with your beige trousers
on, that's the one you'd buy.

But the Panda is
just a car,

whereas this is a car
and a fashion item.

And you'd have to say
that on the style front.

Fiat's done rather
a good job.

I mean, everything in here
wasn't on the original 500.

It's got automatic air-conditioning
and electric windows,

and buttons on the steering
wheel, but the feel of it,

this pseudo-metal dash
and these buttons.

And the big single
instrument and so on.
It even has...
...a retro horn.
Prices start at £8,000,

which means, although
it is dearer than a Panda,

it's a good three grand less
than the cheapest Mini.

And although it's about six
inches shorter than a Mini,

it's actually more
spacious inside.

But the thing about the Mini is that under
its retro skin, it drives brilliantly.

So the question now is, has
Fiat pulled off the same trick?

Well, its home turf
will be the city.

So we've brought it to one,
Budapest in Hungary.

I've come here because
a couple of years ago

I raced some parkour jumpers
through Liverpool in a Peugeot 207,
and lost.

And now some blokes
have been in touch and said,

"How do you fancy
losing again?"

The difference this time is that
they're not big, tough parkour jumpers.

They're actually just
scallywags on BMX bikes.

These wasters just
ride around aimlessly,

like those kids
in the E.T. film.

So to borrow the phrase of the
ancient philosopher, Clarksonius,

4th century BC,
"How hard can it be?"

The race covers eight miles and
starts in the old part of the city, Buda.

We go down the hill,
across the bridge into Pest,

on to the edge of the city
and the giant industrial area,

where we will finish in the biggest
bicycle factory of the Soviet era.
Three, two, one, go!
Now we're off.

And I've lost sight
of them already.

They're not going to last long
doing that sort of thing.

On the hairpins down the hill, the
handling was classic Italian town car.

Ooh! Quite a bit of body roll,
but it's fine.

Just adds to
the amusement value.

Leaving the old town,
heading towards the bridge,

and the BMX bandits
were struggling to keep up.
Bloody hell!

But the bandits are
made of stern stuff.

And on the snarled up bridge,
I lost my lead.
But only for a moment.

Right, this is a crucial overtaking
opportunity. I know what I can do here.

Then we hit red lights,
which I couldn't get around.
No!
But they could.
Oh, come on.

Since I was losing,
I got back to road testing.

You can have this car with
1.2 or 1.4 litre petrol engines,

or you can have the engine I
have here, which is the diesel,
which is rubbish.

The whole point of a small Fiat is
that you have a very small engine in it,
powered by petrol.

You rev it and rev it
and rev it until the valves

come out and dance around on top of
the bonnet, and then you change gear.

I'd lost all
sight of the bandits.

Yet again,
they'd gone to ground.

Something I really like here is
the rev counter in the speedometer.

One is inside the other,
so the speed

chases the revs up and
down the dial. It's terrific.

On the edge of town,
still close,

we enter the great
Soviet industrial park,

for the final
stage in the race.
Bicycles!
Oh, crickey!
Come on, diesel!

Where the hell
are those people?
There they are.

I can see them
in the mirror.

But watch this. If I'm very skilful
here, I can box them in a bit.

There you are,
parked on a lorry.
What?
No!
I can see the flag.
Oh, no, I can see them.
No!
In Hungarian.
You lost.

- Congratulations.
- Thank you.
Well done.
Now go and get a proper bike.

- You get a proper car.
- Yeah, yeah.

- That wasn't really a race, was it?
- No. That was a road test of a Fiat 500,

punctuated by some children on BMX bicycles
leaping over things for no apparent reason.

Yeah, now the thing is, when you came back
from Hungary, you said you preferred

- the Panda to this.
- Yes. The Panda is actually more fun

to drive, and to be honest this is
a bit too "coochie-coochie-coo".

Who here would rather have a Panda?
You see, no-one. 100% of the British

- population think you're wrong.
- But...

But nothing. Because it's now time to put
a star in our reasonably-priced car.

Now, my guest tonight has been a doctor,
he's been murdered, and he was recently

appointed the Sheriff of Nottingham. And
his real life is even more far-fetched.

Ladies and gentlemen,
please welcome Keith Allen!

- How are you?
- Good to see you.

- Have a seat.
- Thank you.

Now, where do we start with you?
You've got eight children by seven women.

- Not true.
- Seven children by six? - No.

- How many... officially made children?
- Don't know.

By seven, and one of course-
Six by four.

- Six by four, is it?
- I believe so, yes.

You had a pet lion
when he was squatting
you've been to a comprehensive school,

- public school, borstal and detention centre.
- Yep.

- Is a borstal fun?
- It's the best of

- the lot. - Was it?
- Yeah.

- Wasn't it all marching though in borstals?
- Yeah but
there's a great way to undermine

- marching. - How?
- Well you're supposed to
march like that,

- aren't you? - Yeah.
- But with enough work, you can go
one two three squat, and then right then

- you can do... You can everybody doing that?
- Of course.

- It's fun.
- One of my highlights,

having looked into your past, is why you
got expelled from boarding school.

Well, there were a lot of
contributing factors

and the major one was, um, I went into the
chapel, and changed all the organ pipes.

- That's an immense job.
- It was just fantastic.

- "And today we will sing Jerusalem..."
- That's a brilliant idea!
I've always loved intelligent vandalism.

Well you know, like an idiot you know when
everyone was going "Who's that?"

It's me going...
Now, your car history is...

isn't exactly conventional, well I wouldn't
suppose we would have expected it to be

- conventional, to be honest.
- Now my first

car was an A35
and then my second car

was a Morris 1000,
with a Riley 1444

- engine in it.
- Is that interesting?

No, I thought that-
if you cut this interview together

in a certain way, at least
it'll look like we had

something to do.
No, you-I mean

- are you a car fan?
- No I'm not.
'Cause I've got to say I keep my cars

- until they're dead.
- Hmm. - And then I'll buy

another one. Uh, my, my car of the moment
is uh, is a 1994 Jag XJ6 3.2.

- A 3.2? I had one of those.
- And I'll keep that

until I run into the ground.
'Cause I'm quite into, believe it or not,
Jeremy, saving the planet, and I believe

- you are as well.
- Yeah. - I think you're a

- much misunderstood man, um...
- You did keep a pig in your car?

Yeah, I was doing a film in Wales
and my co-star was a piglet. And they

thought it would be a really good idea
if I went up to meet the piglet, and took

- it home with me.
- Why did they think that?

- Well, so that it gets used to you, maybe you get on with it...
- Okay, alright, yeah.

Stuff like that. So I did, I took it back
to my partner, who really didn't want a

pig in that house,
so I kept it in the car.

- Mmm, not very wise move.
- Is it it's in the

- handbrake because I didn't realise, 'til the next sunny day, at least.
- Well, there we

are. You're in good shape with your
3.2 and your Riley-engined Mark II to

- take on our lap. - Oh God.
- No, now are you a

- thrillseeker in any way?
- What do

- you think?
- I think you probably are. I suspect that you do quite like a buzz.

Yeah, I mean there is a part of me.
Basically when you come and do this, I've

got to say it's the most terrifying
experience of your life, right? You know

when you see ski Sunday and they're
coming down the mountain, you just think
"I can do that."

Do you know what I mean?
Becaus what you

do is you think it's going like that.
But actually it's going like that and you

- don't see that on television.
- What, the

- track does that?
- No, I swear to you the

- first time you get in the car with that Tibetan Stig...
- Tibetan Stig.

And he starts going round
the track, and I've got to

say he said it's the worst weather they'd
ever experienced here's what you told me.

- Yeah.
- And you get on this straight and

there's a kind of some tyres there, you
think well he's obviously not turning

there, haha! He goes straight on here at
100 mph... "What are you doing!?"

And then he turned it, and he lost it, and
he was so apologetic but. I'm

- telling you, we skidded for 300 yards.
- Are you saying the Stig span?

- Well hang on, fuck Stig, what about me?
- I'm genuinely

- startled I've never-I saw him hit the tyres in a Koenigsegg once.
- Honestly Jeremy,

I swear to you at the end of it he was like
"I've never done that, I've never done
that!" In Tibetan "I've never done it!"

Well of course you did eventually get
into the car by yourself, and we have a

- clip of one of your early practices so who'd like to see that?
- Haha.

And this is what happened.
Here we go, oh

that's an easy- and it's like you lose it
that way, then that way, then that way,

then that way, and brake,
and that way and then spin! Yes!
That's the best spin!
That is such a good spin!

Right, who would like
to see Keith's real lap?
Play the tape.
Oh, I see what you mean about the weather.

Look at the windscreen
wipers! Okay, let's have this.
That is a really wet day.

That's like Steve Coogan came here once-
I'm telling you, it was horrendous.
Well, that's properly unpleasant.

Nevertheless, that's a good line.
Here we go, Chicago, aiming for the tyres.

- Look, 1 mile an hour!
- You would go I promise you-

- I know!
- That's good.

No, that is good in those conditions I
wouldn't want to be going-here we go

this is always a tricky one, put the cone
out so you can see well the corner is.

- It's nicely done.
- I went round.

- It's nicely done, Keith.
- I tried to hit the cameraman here.
I did, I did!

Right, here we go, you missed
that-ooh, that's dangerous,

going across-
Look at that, look!

That's a hundred miles an hour.
I believe in you, Stig.

I do believe in you.
I came off much later then.
I'm going for it.

- Whoa!
- That's a hundred through there!

And now getting even
faster going down here.

- You're not enjoying the car.
- Oh my God.

Here we go, round Gambon... ooh nicely held
bit of a slide there, and there we are
across the line!

Well, here we are now. Obviously, that was
pouring down, standing water, the lot so

realistically, you got to take four
seconds, probably four seconds off.

- So where do you reckon?
- Well I tell you what

when you say, when you say "One minute", if
it has the word "40" in it, I don't care

- what else it is, I'll be pleased.
- Yeah well it can't, because it's pouring

- with rain. So you get to.
- No I know that.

Take four seconds off in your mind.
You ready?

- So it's 1:50... - Ohh... embarrasing.
- It's not embarrassing

- in the rain. 1:51.7, so you go.
- Phwoar!
There.

Oh wait a minute...
I'll give you a "Very Wet", alright?

If you took the four seconds off, I
would actually have 1:47

- point...
- Yeah, you would have been right up

with the Trevor Reeves and the Lawrence
Dallaglios of this world, and that is,

I promise you, that was very good
driving and I'm not making that up.

- Thank you.
- Does Lily wanna come down and do it?

- Yeah. Desperate.
- Does she?

- Oh yeah.
- We've never had father and daughter before.

- Yeah, she desperately wants to do it.
- What if she beat you?

I wouldn't mind at all.
As long as she's alive...

- Well of course she's gonna be alive!
- At the end of it.

Yeah, Keith, it's been a pleasure to have
you down here, absolute star,

thank you so much for coming.
Ladies and gentlemen, Keith Allen!
Thank you very much.

Good, very good. And that's a good time.
Thank you. It's good, it's good!
Now, bad news.

Jeremy was summoned to
the producer's office this week

and told, "No more supercars
on our test track for this series."

- Aw!
- I know. He was most insistent.

He said we'd had
too many and it was time.

Jeremy went out and
reviewed a proper family car.
So, here we go.

This is
a Daihatsu Materia.

It's a small and easy to park
five-door hatchback.

Now, what I thought I'd do
is compare it to a rival,

a competitor product
of some sort.

The producer liked
that idea very much,

so what I've done is
brought along this.
It's the Ascari A10,

a carbon-fibre powerhouse with a five-litre
V8 from an old BMW M5 in the back.

I think it's better-looking
than the Daihatsu.

And with 625 horsepower
on tap, it's also much louder.
Quicker, too.

In fact, it's quicker
than almost anything.
It is insanely fast.

Put your foot down, and
instantly, you're somewhere else,

very, very far away
from where you were.

Zero to 60
takes 2.8 seconds.

Flat out, you'll be doing
215 miles an hour,

and sign language for the rest
of your life because you'll be deaf.

Of course, you might
imagine that because

it was conceived by
a Dutch billionaire

and built on an industrial
estate in Banbury,

that it's all
a bit half-cocked.

And sure,
the interior is as luxurious

and as well-finished
as an army Land Rover.

But the way this thing
drives beggars belief.

It's funny, because
it's not a heavy car, this.

It doesn't weigh much more
than a family hatchback,

but it feels like
it's running on coal.

It feels like it's from
the Industrial Revolution.

It feels like I should
really be sitting here

with a dirty face
and a Davy lamp.

I just love this
sequential gearbox.

It's as manly as Lawrence
Dallaglio's jockstrap.

And then there's the steering,
which is even better.

Because it's so good
and so perfectly weighted,

you have the confidence to
take this car by the wedding veg,
and go absolutely berserk.
